title: Wishing Well
description: On “Wishing Well,“ the late rapper Juice WRLD discusses substance abuse and fame, dropping references to his drug of choice,  Percocet . What began as recreational drug use morphed into an addiction that ultimately led to his early death at the tender age of 21. Juice seemingly predicted his own demise on his June 2018  tribute  to  XXXTENTACION  and  Lil Peep , who also died young: On December 8, 2019, Juice WRLD suffered an  accidental overdose at Midway International Airport  in Chicago. He reportedly swallowed multiple pills after law enforcement attempted to intercept his crew upon suspicion of gun and drug possession. The Cook County Medical Examiner confirmed that fatal levels of codeine and oxycodone were present in his body—the latter of which is found in Percocet, or “Perky,” as it is called in the song’s chorus. Before its official release, the song was previewed in March 2018 on Instagram Live. It was then leaked on October 6, 2019, with an extended verse.

annotations.referent: I cry out for help, do they listen?
annotations.annotation: Juice WRLD is often known for crying out through his music about his struggles with drug addiction – the struggle which ultimately took his life. As he often cried out in his music and to his fans, Jarad battled with prescription drug dependency and depression.

Juice WRLD may have called back to this line on the thirteenth track from March 2019’s Death Race for Love, titled “Ring Ring”:Ring, ring-ringI don’t feel like comin' to the phone todayJuice also raps about depression, a topic that he frequents on many of his tracks. For example, on May 2018’s “I’m Still,” he says:You’re my depressionYour first impression was in deception, you were lyin'

annotations.referent:
I still try even though I know I’m gon’ fail
 Stress on my shoulders like a anvil
 Perky got me itching like a anthill
annotations.annotation: Juice is struggling to cope with the pressure that the music industry places on him, and relates this to the heavy metalworking tool, the anvil.

annotations.referent: Sometimes I don’t know how to feel
annotations.annotation: Juice refers to having mixed emotions as he enjoys the satisfaction of taking pills yet knowing that the drugs are slowly taking over him and killing him “softly.

annotations.referent:
This is the part where I tell you I’m fine, but I’m lying
 I just don’t want you to worry
 This is the part where I take all my feelings and hide ’em
 ’Cause I don’t want nobody to hurt me
annotations.annotation: The pre-chorus notes Juice’s struggles with showing his feelings and insecurities, which is an issue he’s discussed numerous times prior – in both his music and on social media.

annotations.referent:
You used my past and my memories as a weapon
 On the other line, I talk to addiction, huh
annotations.annotation: While experiencing depression, a person’s negative memories can often feel even worse, as they tend to ruminate over and over again over tense times, making the symptoms worsen. In this hypothetical phone call, Juice speaks to his other main struggle, addiction.
